Scholars of world-wide renOwn
will participate in the Fiftieth Anniversary Celebration of the Johns
Hopkins University, to be held on
Friday and Saturday of this week.
Nearly two thousand alumni will
attend in addition to a small number of outsiders.
The celebration is being made,
as far as possible, an all-Hopkins
party. It is true that the chief
speakers are men who have
crossed the Atlantic to be present,
but there have been no general invitations extended among the universities of the country, as is
sometimes the custom in connection with functions of a similar
nature.
Dr. Andrew Balfour, Director
of the London School of Hygiene
and Tropical Medicine, will deliver the principal address on Friday at the exercises commemorating the opening of the School of
Hygiene and Public Health, while
Dr. L. Livy-Bruhl, noted philosopher of the Sorbonne, will perform the same function on the following day at the fiftieth anniversary of the Philosophical Faculty.
On Friday afternoon, the period
from three to six o'clock will be
taken up by individual conferences of every department of the
University. This includes both
the faculties of philosophy and

A NEW ERA?
All sorts of platitudes can and will be uttered this week concerning the greatness of the Johns Hopkins University. Newspapers all over the United States, and probably in parts of
Europe, will pay tribute to the fiftieth anniversary of America's
foremost Medical School and Graduate School. It is obviously
not for us to waste words echoing such sentiments.
Though the preponderance of these who have seen fit to comment upon the so-called New, Plan of President Goodnow have
hailed it as a vast step forward in the field of education itself,
few, if any have looked for a deeper significance which may manifest itself as a positive s.tep forward toward the ultimate enrichment of actual human felicity.
We wonder if there did not lurk in the mind of President
Goodnow an ideal loftier than the mere training of a few more
M. A.'s and Ph. D.'s. The building up of the Graduate School
has been the feature of the plan which has received the most
emphasis; the granting of a more falorable environment to
would-be doctors of philosophy has received the approval of many
eminent educators.
But what probably is the basis and the stimulation of the
plan of the President is a sincere belief in the final efficacy of the
motto of Johns Hopkins University—"Veritas vos liberavit".
For he believes that the creation of the university of his dreams
will awaken the dormant talents of potential Darwins, Kants,
Lavoisiers, or Spencers.
We cannot help but believe that President Goodnow is fostering a hope that the Johns Hopkins of the future will be a
haven for benefactors of the human race. The Johns _Hopkins
that he visualizes will be the home of far-reaching researches in all
fields of knowledge: it will be a magnet drawing to it the great
minds and curious truth-seekers of the globe.
The New Plan, if analyzed more than superficially, is not
purely a scheme for a glorified Graduate School. It embodies
much more than an extended opportunity for "higher education":
it is an attempt to make an ideal a reality. It is the predication
of a further search for the so-far elusive philosopher's stone, and
as such is a glorious ideal.
We of the Undergraduate Department are prone to look
askance at such extreme idealism. Many of us will condemn the
dream as sheer sentimentality. We may criticise it on many
other grounds than these.
But in the last analysis, despite any objections of a practical nature that might be raised against the inauguration of the
New Plan as outlined herewith, we are forced to admit that it
iF a gorgeous ideal. We hope that it will become more than that.
This week may be the beginning of a new era. It may set
the cornerstone of a new search for Truth. Or it may be merely
the fiftieth anniversary of an American university. Who will
venture a guess?

YES AND NO
The Shanghi Gesture
You are in New York in, let us say 1880. You are a
sailor. Having been paid off some four months previously,
your money is nearly gone. The necessity of having something to do presents itself in the form of unpaid room rent.
Picking up whatever clothing you happen to possess, it is
plunged into a sea-bag and you hie yourself to a waterfront
bar where there will be talk of ships and sailings ; of skippers
and bos'ns ; of articles and signing on. But as you pass the
line at the bar and your eye wanders about the tables in the
back room, searching in vain for familiar faces. You decide
that you are desolately lonely.
Suddenly the swinging doors break in the middle and four
of your old shipmates are presented; boisterously happy. One
is with a clipper ship bound for Rio; another in a four master
to Sidney, still another to the East in a mail packet. The other
is going on a trip to the fishing banks that won't amount to
much. Ten minues before you would have welcomed the
chance to go anywhere. It would have been a pleasure. Now
with fair friends bidding you go here and there, you decide to
be choosey.
But since you have last seen your old buddies they have
acquired a deep, dark purpose in life. They are now Bos'ils
for their respective ship-masters. Their orders are to get you
at any price.
Being a social creature, when they suggest getting a drink
or two you join them at the bar. Everything goes stilendidly
for a while. They talk of their ships with a bit of ,swagger
and a deal of pride. The .treat is dutch. Being naturally
cautious you don't drink too much; your head is clear and
you have a pretty fair chance to look them all over.
So far the game is fair, the odds are about even. You go,
as a matter of course, to the man you really like best. The
party decides to have a friendly poker game in the back-room
and you are invited to watch them if you so desire. There is
one man you can't help but like, you like his style of play
and the way he conducts himself in the company of others.
Perhaps he drops you a word or two about the congeniality
of his shipmates., of the standing of his shipping cqmpany. In
the next day or so you meet some of his bunkies and are, so
far as sober judgment will permit, mentally decided that you
will take one trip; you like ship, sailors and company.
But one day when you are not present the whole group
get together and decide. on a plan of action.
The following day you sense a feeling of unrestraint in
theirgreetings. No longer are you asked to be your own
host; wine flows freely at no cost to you; also finding that they
are fairy .folk who drag you about in coaches and money flows
as freely as the wine. A week wears on. Your head is becoming fuzzy, faces are blurred and that little man on the
fishing trip is much in evidence. But wassa diff'runce anyway? You are too tired to think and a bit too drunk to
reason. The little man still buzzes around. S'funny, when
you were sober this little man didn't count for much. But
he doesn't get far away; never leaves you alone. He holds his
liquor well too. . . . Getting more tired and drunker. . .
.Whoozit? ... can't see ... all drunk together ... HEY-A-DEY
. .. go ? ... go? alphabetagammadelta ... wassis ? . .. yesh .. .
s'at lil' guy again. Oh well.
You wake up on November first, nineteen twenty-six,
wearing the uniform of the fishing trip. Around you are other
deck-boys arrived in the same inanner as you. One or two by
choice. The others don't quite know why. You are sure you
don't. If it only hadn't been that one open week! . . . The
little man is not in sight. He is down below decks, asleep
from exhaustion. Perhaps he won't be any good for the rest
of the voyage!! Quien sabe? But he got his man.

The first real business meeting

afternoon at two-thirty.

Scholars of world-wide renOwn
will participate in the Fiftieth Anniversary Celebration of the Johns
Hopkins University, to be held on
Friday and Saturday of this week.
Nearly two thousand alumni will
attend in addition to a small number of outsiders.
The celebration is being made,
as far as possible, an all-Hopkins
party. It is true that the chief
speakers are men who have
crossed the Atlantic to be present,
but there have been no general invitations extended among the universities of the country, as is
sometimes the custom in connection with functions of a similar
nature.
Dr. Andrew Balfour, Director
of the London School of Hygiene
and Tropical Medicine, will deliver the principal address on Friday at the exercises commemorating the opening of the School of
Hygiene and Public Health, while
Dr. L. Livy-Bruhl, noted philosopher of the Sorbonne, will perform the same function on the following day at the fiftieth anniversary of the Philosophical Faculty.
On Friday afternoon, the period
from three to six o'clock will be
taken up by individual conferences of every department of the
University. This includes both
the faculties of philosophy and

A NEW ERA?
All sorts of platitudes can and will be uttered this week concerning the greatness of the Johns Hopkins University. Newspapers all over the United States, and probably in parts of
Europe, will pay tribute to the fiftieth anniversary of America's
foremost Medical School and Graduate School. It is obviously
not for us to waste words echoing such sentiments.
Though the preponderance of these who have seen fit to comment upon the so-called New, Plan of President Goodnow have
hailed it as a vast step forward in the field of education itself,
few, if any have looked for a deeper significance which may manifest itself as a positive s.tep forward toward the ultimate enrichment of actual human felicity.
We wonder if there did not lurk in the mind of President
Goodnow an ideal loftier than the mere training of a few more
M. A.'s and Ph. D.'s. The building up of the Graduate School
has been the feature of the plan which has received the most
emphasis; the granting of a more falorable environment to
would-be doctors of philosophy has received the approval of many
eminent educators.
But what probably is the basis and the stimulation of the
plan of the President is a sincere belief in the final efficacy of the
motto of Johns Hopkins University—"Veritas vos liberavit".
For he believes that the creation of the university of his dreams
will awaken the dormant talents of potential Darwins, Kants,
Lavoisiers, or Spencers.
We cannot help but believe that President Goodnow is fostering a hope that the Johns Hopkins of the future will be a
haven for benefactors of the human race. The Johns _Hopkins
that he visualizes will be the home of far-reaching researches in all
fields of knowledge: it will be a magnet drawing to it the great
minds and curious truth-seekers of the globe.
The New Plan, if analyzed more than superficially, is not
purely a scheme for a glorified Graduate School. It embodies
much more than an extended opportunity for "higher education":
it is an attempt to make an ideal a reality. It is the predication
of a further search for the so-far elusive philosopher's stone, and
as such is a glorious ideal.
We of the Undergraduate Department are prone to look
askance at such extreme idealism. Many of us will condemn the
dream as sheer sentimentality. We may criticise it on many
other grounds than these.
But in the last analysis, despite any objections of a practical nature that might be raised against the inauguration of the
New Plan as outlined herewith, we are forced to admit that it
iF a gorgeous ideal. We hope that it will become more than that.
This week may be the beginning of a new era. It may set
the cornerstone of a new search for Truth. Or it may be merely
the fiftieth anniversary of an American university. Who will
venture a guess?

YES AND NO
The Shanghi Gesture
You are in New York in, let us say 1880. You are a
sailor. Having been paid off some four months previously,
your money is nearly gone. The necessity of having something to do presents itself in the form of unpaid room rent.
Picking up whatever clothing you happen to possess, it is
plunged into a sea-bag and you hie yourself to a waterfront
bar where there will be talk of ships and sailings ; of skippers
and bos'ns ; of articles and signing on. But as you pass the
line at the bar and your eye wanders about the tables in the
back room, searching in vain for familiar faces. You decide
that you are desolately lonely.
Suddenly the swinging doors break in the middle and four
of your old shipmates are presented; boisterously happy. One
is with a clipper ship bound for Rio; another in a four master
to Sidney, still another to the East in a mail packet. The other
is going on a trip to the fishing banks that won't amount to
much. Ten minues before you would have welcomed the
chance to go anywhere. It would have been a pleasure. Now
with fair friends bidding you go here and there, you decide to
be choosey.
But since you have last seen your old buddies they have
acquired a deep, dark purpose in life. They are now Bos'ils
for their respective ship-masters. Their orders are to get you
at any price.
Being a social creature, when they suggest getting a drink
or two you join them at the bar. Everything goes stilendidly
for a while. They talk of their ships with a bit of ,swagger
and a deal of pride. The .treat is dutch. Being naturally
cautious you don't drink too much; your head is clear and
you have a pretty fair chance to look them all over.
So far the game is fair, the odds are about even. You go,
as a matter of course, to the man you really like best. The
party decides to have a friendly poker game in the back-room
and you are invited to watch them if you so desire. There is
one man you can't help but like, you like his style of play
and the way he conducts himself in the company of others.
Perhaps he drops you a word or two about the congeniality
of his shipmates., of the standing of his shipping cqmpany. In
the next day or so you meet some of his bunkies and are, so
far as sober judgment will permit, mentally decided that you
will take one trip; you like ship, sailors and company.
But one day when you are not present the whole group
get together and decide. on a plan of action.
The following day you sense a feeling of unrestraint in
theirgreetings. No longer are you asked to be your own
host; wine flows freely at no cost to you; also finding that they
are fairy .folk who drag you about in coaches and money flows
as freely as the wine. A week wears on. Your head is becoming fuzzy, faces are blurred and that little man on the
fishing trip is much in evidence. But wassa diff'runce anyway? You are too tired to think and a bit too drunk to
reason. The little man still buzzes around. S'funny, when
you were sober this little man didn't count for much. But
he doesn't get far away; never leaves you alone. He holds his
liquor well too. . . . Getting more tired and drunker. . .
.Whoozit? ... can't see ... all drunk together ... HEY-A-DEY
. .. go ? ... go? alphabetagammadelta ... wassis ? . .. yesh .. .
s'at lil' guy again. Oh well.
You wake up on November first, nineteen twenty-six,
wearing the uniform of the fishing trip. Around you are other
deck-boys arrived in the same inanner as you. One or two by
choice. The others don't quite know why. You are sure you
don't. If it only hadn't been that one open week! . . . The
little man is not in sight. He is down below decks, asleep
from exhaustion. Perhaps he won't be any good for the rest
of the voyage!! Quien sabe? But he got his man.

Weekly Meeting
Meeting

The first real business meeting
of the Hullabaloo will be held in
the News-Letter office on Friday, October 21, at 12:30. Positions on the business staff will be
awarded on a competitive basis
and the candidates getting the
most ads will have preference.
The men who come to this meeting will have the best chance of
making the staff as assignments
to interview advertisers of previous years will be given out at this
time.
Advertising Manager Dalserner
desires to see a large number of
candidates on Friday as the Hullabaloo contemplates taking on a
number of new men this year.

The Business Managership, however, can only be obtained by a
man who has had one year of experience on the staff.
An innovation of the Hullabaloo's last year was the large bulletin board for advertisers which
was posted in the Barn. This
board will be put up again this
year by the Hullabaloo and space
on it will be accorded to advertisers in proportion to the size of
their ads.

Two interesting speakers made
up the program of last Thursday's
assembly. Mr. Harry W. Laidler,
of the League for Industrial Democracy, who was introduced by
Dr. Broadus Mitchell, spoke on
growing cooperation in •industry.
Dr. Isaac Yonan, President of the
Urumia University in Persia, told
of the work done by the Unit.d
States in the Near East. Brinton Stone, president of the Student Council, announced that On
the twenty-eighth of October
there will be no assembly. Instead of having assembly on that
day, he urged everyone to hear the
Bishop of London, who will
speak at the Lyric on the same
afternoon at two-thirty.
